intro: Agatea longipedicellata, commonly known as the long-stalked agatea, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the family Malvaceae and is characterized by its showy, pink to purple flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant has palmate leaves with five to seven lobes, and its stems are often covered in soft, fuzzy hairs. Agatea longipedicellata is typically found in moist, sandy soils along stream banks and in wetlands. It plays an important role in local ecosystems by providing nectar for pollinators and habitat for various insects.
